  2. Contact the Seller First: Politely approach the seller with your proof and ask for a resolution.
  3. Escalate if Necessary: If the seller doesn't help, file a complaint with a consumer forum or call the National Consumer Helpline (1915).

practice_questions.question: You bought a new pen that doesn't write. What is the first step you should take?
practice_questions.answer: The first step is to go back to the shopkeeper with the pen and the receipt to ask for a replacement or refund.

subtopics.title: Day 6: Role-Play Activity
subtopics.content:
Putting Your Knowledge into Action

Knowing your rights is one thing, but being able to assert them politely and effectively is another. By role-playing common scenarios, you can practice how you would handle a real-life situation.

Activity Instructions:

Pair up with a classmate or a friend. One person will be the 'Customer' and the other will be the 'Shopkeeper'. Act out one or more of the following scenarios:

  • Scenario 1: The MRP Overcharge. The customer wants to buy a cold drink with an MRP of ₹20. The shopkeeper is trying to charge ₹25 for 'cooling charges'.
  • Scenario 2: The Defective Product. The customer bought a t-shirt yesterday and discovered a small hole in it. They have the receipt and want a replacement.
  • Scenario 3: The Forced Bundle. The customer wants to buy a pen, but the shopkeeper says they must also buy a notebook with it.

The goal is to calmly and clearly state the problem and your right. Being polite but firm is the most effective approach.

practice_questions.question: In a role-play, if a shopkeeper refuses to give a refund for a defective product, what should the 'customer' say or do next?
practice_questions.answer: The customer should calmly state that they will escalate the issue by filing a complaint with the consumer forum and mention that they have the receipt as proof.

subtopics.title: Day 7: Revision and Assessment
subtopics.content:
Your Consumer Rights Toolkit: A Final Review

Let's review the key rights we've learned this week. Being an aware and informed consumer is a lifelong skill that not only protects you but also helps promote a fair and honest marketplace for everyone.

Your Rights at a Glance:

Right to Safety

Protection from hazardous goods.

Right to be Informed

Access to information about product quality, price, etc.

Right to Choose

Access to a variety of goods at competitive prices.

Right to be Heard

Your complaints must be considered.

Right to Seek Redressal

Right to a remedy for unfair practices.

Right to Consumer Education

The right to acquire knowledge to be an informed consumer.

National Consumer Helpline: 1915

Remember this number. It's a simple, powerful tool. Don't hesitate to use it to raise your voice against unfair practices. Your voice matters!

practice_questions.question: What is the national consumer helpline number in India?
practice_questions.answer: The national consumer helpline number is 1915.

lessons.title: Module 11: Basic Law for Teens
lessons.description: Introduction to Rights & Responsibilities, Cyber Laws, and Legal Awareness

subtopics.title: Day 1: Introduction to Law and the Legal System
subtopics.content:
The Rulebook for Society

Law is a system of rules that a society develops to deal with crime, business agreements, and social relationships. Think of it like the official rulebook for a game—the rules exist to make sure everyone can play fairly and safely. Without laws, there would be chaos.

The Main Goals of Law:

  • To protect people from harm.
  • To protect people's property.
  • To ensure fairness in our interactions.
  • To help resolve disagreements peacefully.

Your rights and responsibilities are two sides of the same coin. You have the right to be safe, and in return, you have the responsibility not to harm others.

practice_questions.question: What is the main purpose of having laws in society?
practice_questions.answer: To protect people and their property, maintain order, ensure fairness, and help resolve disputes peacefully.

subtopics.title: Day 2: Understanding Your Rights
subtopics.content:
Your Shield of Protection

As a citizen, and especially as a young person, you are entitled to certain fundamental rights that are designed to protect your dignity, freedom, and well-being. Knowing these rights is the first step to being able to defend them.

Key Rights You Should Know:

Right to Equality

The law must treat you equally. You cannot be discriminated against based on religion, race, gender, caste, or place of birth.

Right to Freedom of Speech & Expression

You have the right to share your opinions. However, this right comes with the responsibility not to spread hate or cause harm.

Right to Education & Safety

You have a fundamental right to access education and to be protected from physical, mental, and emotional harm.

Right to Privacy

Your personal information, communications, and private life should be protected from unwarranted intrusion.

practice_questions.question: What should you do if your right to education is violated?
practice_questions.answer: You can report it to school authorities, educational boards, or child rights organizations.

subtopics.title: Day 3: Understanding Your Responsibilities
subtopics.content:
The Social Contract: Your Role in Society

Being part of a society is a two-way street. In exchange for the rights and protections society gives you, you have certain responsibilities you must uphold. This is the 'social contract' that allows us all to live together peacefully.

Your Key Responsibilities:

Obey Laws

This is the most basic duty. Follow traffic rules, respect property, and don't engage in illegal activities.

Respect the Rights of Others

Respect their property, their privacy, and their opinions, even if you disagree.

Do Not Bully or Harass

You have a direct responsibility to help create a safe and respectful environment for your peers, online and off.

Be Accountable

Part of growing up is taking responsibility for your actions, good and bad. Admit when you've made a mistake and learn from it.

practice_questions.question: What to do if you break something at a friend’s house?
practice_questions.answer: Take responsibility, apologize, and offer to pay for or replace the item.

subtopics.title: Day 4: Cyber Laws - Digital Rights and Responsibilities
subtopics.content:
The Law Follows You Online

A common mistake is to think that the digital world is a lawless space. This is not true. The same laws and ethical rules that apply in the real world also apply online. Digital crimes have real-world consequences.

Key Cyber Laws You Need to Know:

  • Cyberbullying & Harassment: Repeatedly targeting, threatening, or humiliating someone online is a serious offense.
  • Identity Theft: Creating fake profiles, hacking accounts, or using someone's personal information without permission is illegal.
  • Copyright Infringement: You cannot legally copy and distribute someone else's creative work (music, movies, images) without their permission.
  • Online Fraud: This includes phishing scams, fake online stores, and any other attempt to trick people out of their money online.

Remember, your digital footprint is largely permanent. Think before you post, share, or click.

practice_questions.question: Is sharing embarrassing photos without consent legal?
practice_questions.answer: No, it can be considered a form of harassment or cyberbullying and may have legal consequences.

subtopics.title: Day 5: Social Media and Gaming Laws
subtopics.content:
The Fine Print: Understanding Terms of Service

When you sign up for a platform like Instagram or a game like Fortnite, you are agreeing to a legally binding contract: the Terms of Service (ToS). While no one reads the full document, it's important to understand the key rules.

Key ToS Points

  • Age Restrictions: Most platforms have a minimum age (usually 13) to comply with data privacy laws.
  • Content Moderation: The platform has the right to remove content that violates their policies (hate speech, harassment, etc.).
  • Data Collection: The terms outline what data the platform collects and how they use it (often for ads).

Gaming Laws

Laws are evolving around things like 'loot boxes' in games. Some jurisdictions view them as a form of gambling for minors and are putting restrictions on them. It is your responsibility to abide by the rules of the digital spaces you inhabit.

practice_questions.question: What legal steps should you consider if starting a business on social media?
practice_questions.answer: You need to follow the platform's commercial use policies, be honest in advertising, and handle customer data securely.

subtopics.title: Day 6: Case Studies and Real-World Applications
subtopics.content:
When Digital Actions End Up in Court

Let's look at how these laws are applied in the real world. It's important to know that the legal system often treats young offenders (minors) differently than adults. The focus is often on rehabilitation and education rather than just punishment.

Case Examples for Discussion:

The Cyberbullying Case

Severe, ongoing online harassment could lead to legal charges. For a minor, the outcome would likely be mandatory counseling and restorative justice (like apologizing to the victim) rather than jail time.

The Viral Video Case

A student who records a private, embarrassing video of a classmate and posts it online could face serious legal consequences for invasion of privacy and distribution of inappropriate content.

The Academic Fraud Case

Using AI to cheat on an exam can not only lead to school suspension but can also seriously harm your reputation for future college and job applications.

The key takeaway is that even if the intent was just a 'joke,' the impact on the victim is what matters in the eyes of the law.

practice_questions.question: How can you support a friend who is a victim of cyberbullying?
practice_questions.answer: Listen to them, save evidence, help them report it to trusted adults and the platform, and offer emotional support.

subtopics.title: Day 7: Mock Court Activity and Review
subtopics.content:
You Be the Judge!

Today's activity is a mock court trial where you get to put everything you've learned this week into practice. This role-playing exercise will help you understand the legal process from different perspectives.

The Case:

After a heated argument, a student secretly records a video of another student crying in the hallway. They edit the video to make it more embarrassing, add a mocking caption, and post it on a school-wide social media group where it goes viral.

The Roles to Play:

  • Judge: Oversees the trial, keeps order, and ensures fairness.
  • Prosecution Team: Argues that the student broke the law (e.g., invasion of privacy, harassment).
  • Defense Team: Argues on behalf of the accused student (e.g., it was just a joke, they didn't intend for it to go viral).
  • Jury: Listens to all the evidence and arguments and decides on the outcome.

This activity highlights the complexity of legal issues, the importance of evidence, and why prevention through education is always a better solution than punishment.

practice_questions.question: In the mock trial, what evidence could prove an intent to harm?
practice_questions.answer: Evidence could include threatening messages sent before the incident, captions on the video, or testimony about the argument.
